text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
battles dross glop records stored a just
happened this past weekend hope
everybody had a good record store I got
a few things one of which is the new
high on fire record got that on vinyl
double LP fantastic pressing really
great album art I got that
mc5 Afrika Bambaataa 7-inch I talked
about in one of my videos and I totally
completed my battles remix series like a
complete nerd so now that I got all four
of those remix 12-inches I figure hey
you know it'd be a good idea let's
review the dross Club album so battles
is an experimental rock band that
underwent some pretty big changes on its
sophomore LP that got released last year
gloss drop they had just lost a pivotal
member of the group and they were kind
of working through the change by
bringing on a bunch of guest vocalists
not only that but their tracks were
feeling much brighter much more playful
and upbeat to me the band was just
taking its trademark tight sound in a
much more colorful and bright direction
on that second LP battles just had the
intricacy of a math rock band which is
not surprising considering the the
group's ties to bands like Don Caballero
and links but they also jammed like an
improvisational rock group but these
really hard intense relentless grooves
it's almost nothing but fire on every
track and the whole LP is just can
to me I can't say no because of all
those attributes gloss drop landed in my
top 10 of favorite albums last year so
of course I am totally interested in
hearing a series of remixes for every
single song from this album no matter
how bad they are especially considering
the lineup of people remixes these songs
few I have have done reviews for Shabazz
Palaces Hudson Mohawke the Field Jacket
AMA I who was a guest vocalist on the
last track from the album as well as
code-nine and kangding Rey but-but-but I
usually do not enjoy remix albums and I
usually do not review them either for
one there's usually not much in the way
of a flow or consistency since what
you're really talking about here at the
end of the day is kind of like a
compilation of different artists all
remix in songs in their own way there's
bound to be some stylistic clashing and
rarely are remix albums so good that
they appeal outside of the fan base of
people who are extremely passionate
about the album that is being remixed
aka
people like me but for a remix album
Dras Club is pretty consistent
I don't know how most of the people on
this album ended up kind of cooking with
the same ingredients I guess but a
majority of the tracks on this album to
me kind of ended up being very deep and
micro house esque tunes with very
constant rhythms that subtly subtly
shift and progress over periods of six
seven eight or even nine minutes some
tracks are so faint with their changes
and their sounds they almost border on
being ambient not to say there is a
variety on here those Shabazz Palaces
definitely comes in and does its thing
as well as Yaka Tama I which I will
kinda
talk about a little bit later I feel
like I ended up disappointed with a good
chunk of these tracks individually
especially given who was remix in the
song my life for what I thought code 9
would definitely put something together
that was more akin to his dubstep roots
it wasn't a bad remix I just thought
maybe he played things a little too
straight and I thought Hudson Mohawke
would put together a serious banger on
this album but he just whipped up a
version of rolls Basie that sounds
pretty much like the original but less
is going on less original but less and I
guess my even bigger disappointments
with this thing are the moments where
the tracks don't even resemble the
originals in any way shape or form
really to the point where I wonder what
the remix and and the original really
have to do with one another other than
the fact that they're on this every
artist on this thing is going to have a
different remix in process and different
thoughts I understand that but this
album did get me thinking what makes for
good remix and for me personally of
course it has to feel different than the
original noticeably different but also
the point of reference the original
needs to be so clear and obvious in a
way that you end up seeing the original
the remix material in a different light
from a different perspective and that's
where I kind of feel like the silent
servant remix them and the cluster remix
fall a little short because even though
I'm sure it's somewhere there either
influencing the keyboards being played
or being sampled that point of reference
that sonic point of reference isn't
really there the track dominican fate
has these lightly played keyboards
placed on top of these quirky quirky
beats there's not really a blatant
sample on this track or anything like
that it seems as if the keyboards and
the drum machine
which are pretty much the track itself
were all original but still not really
seeing that point of reference
ultimately the song to me kind of sounds
like a collaboration between OneNote
Rick's point never and beach houses drum
machine but I also feel like the my
machines and an ice cream remixes would
feel pretty far away from the originals
too if it weren't for the fact that the
vocals from the original songs are so
obviously sampled and executed I will
give it to Gang Gang dance and Brian
Brian Brian I guess I was just kind of
underwhelmed by a lot of these tracks
the Shabazz Palaces remix I'm not as in
love with now as I am when I first heard
it the beat is very spacious as it would
be on Shabazz Palaces last album black
up palace ear Lazaro's vocals are
doubled up soaked and reverb very bouncy
trippy kind of psychedelic but the
lyrics aren't that mind-bending or
clever to me not as much as they have
been with Shabazz Palaces tracks in the
past you know it's not all complaints
with this album though I did think the
first several tracks were pretty solid
the wallstreet remix has a really great
groove and some swelling strings on the
refrain that really make the track feel
refined and the field remix on here
sweetie and shag is great he totally
brought that looping state of mind sort
of execution making all of these cycling
sections of sound feels so hypnotic and
I thought the track future it was great
too with this nice constant hip-hop beat
backing up the chords of the song kind
of playing in the foreground the thing
is I did not think this remix album was
terrible I liked most of the tracks but
was really really only in love with a
couple the biggest problem is that this
remix album brings a completely
different energy than gloss drop this
album does not feel high-energy it does
not feel fun it does not feel playful it
does not really feel all that engaging
in some points it does not feel high
octave
it doesn't feel like the entire world is
is on fire and in M&M candy shell in
contrast dross cloth is is just much
more chill repetitive kind of relaxed
with these very heady electronica tunes
that may or may not even sound like the
tracks that they are supposed to be
remixed in or if you're a huge fan of
some of the remixers on this thing kind
of feeling a strong 5-2 ally six on this
to be completely honest I mean yeah I
